comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: This may be the house of Arthur Capper at 1035 Topeka Boulevard. When he served as governor from 1915 to 1919, he lived in his own house rather than the governor's mansion -- which looked nothing like this. See www.kshs.org/p/cool-things-stained-glass-windows/10277

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: In Kansas: A Guide to the Sunflower State (a 1939 publication of the Federal Writers Project), books.google.com/books?id=prI_kG_QmvoC&pg=PA290&l... Capper's house, then the headquarters of WIBW Radio & TV, stations he owned, is described as "a two-story limestone and concrete structure of the Italian villa type." So this could well be that house. According to this publication, the house was on the NW corner of Topeka Blvd and 11th St, designed by Root & Seimans [sic -- actually Siemens] of Kansas City and completed in 1912. The following governor also lived in the house -- while Capper was a Senator. cjonline.com/stories/120202/wib_history.shtml indicates that WIBW moved in in 1934 after remodeling, and remained there for 20 years.

comment.author: 34911459@N08
comment._content: swanq: thank you for the background information.  We may update the record.

comment.author: 40635977@N04
comment._content: Again, this wasn't the Governor's Mansion.
